column3: the tax checkoff published in december contents what happens to my three dollars who receives the checkoff dollars why did congress adopt the public funding law may any candidate receive the public funds must candidates accept public funds in the general election do candidates benefit from any other financial resources besides the public funds how much money has been given out how do candidates spend their funds does anyone monitor candidates use of funds who administers the checkoff program is the checkoff used for administering the public funding program what would happen if checkoff dollars ran short does checking yes increase my tax the taxpayer choice do you want of your federal tax to go to the presidential election campaign fund yes no as a taxpayer you are asked to make this choice when you fill out your federal income tax return before you exercise that choice you may have some questions what is the checkoff for who receives the money how is the money spent does the checkoff increase my tax this brochure provides some answers what happens to my three dollars when you check yes three of your tax dollars are placed in the presidential election campaign fund during each of the last five years approximately million taxpayers have checked the yes box every four years the federal government distributes dollars from the fund sometimes called public funds or federal funds to qualified presidential candidates and national party committees for use in the presidential elections whatever money is left over at the end of the presidential election remains in the fund and is used in the next election four years later who receives the checkoff dollars presidential nominees in the general election the republican and democratic nominees in the general election receive a fixed amount of checkoff dollars nominees from other political parties may qualify for a smaller proportionate amount of checkoff funds if they receive over five percent of the vote presidential primary candidates candidates in the presidential primaries may receive checkoff dollars in the form of matching funds contributions of up to from individuals are matched dollar for dollar pac and party contributions are not matchable party nominating conventions the national parties receive checkoff funds to cover the costs of their national conventions held every four years to select their presidential nominees why did congress adopt the public funding law congress set up the checkoff in the early as an alternative way of funding presidential elec tions candidates that choose to accept public funds can reduce their dependence on large contributions from individuals and groups in the general election the public funding system places the two major-party nominees on an equal financial footing in the campaign may any candidate receive the public funds no the federal election commission fec certifies the eligibility only of those candidates who meet the strict qualifications established by congress checkoff dollars are given only to presidential candidates who demonstrate broad national support general election nominees must agree not to accept any private contributions from individuals or pacs for example candidates must promise not to spend more than of their own money on their campaign recipients of public funds must adhere to a limit on total spending must candidates accept public funds no a candidate may choose not to participate in the public funding program in that case the candi date is not bound by the expenditure limits in the general election do candidates benefit from any other financial resources besides the public funds yes individuals and political committees may spend money to publicly express their support for or against candidates provided there is no coordination with the campaign additionally the law allows party committees to spend a limited amount on behalf of their presidential nominees how much money has been given out for the general election the law provides a fixed amount indexed to inflation in each major-party nominee received million by reflecting inflationary trends that amount grew to million in the presidential primaries the total amount paid to campaigns varies from year to yea in primary candidates received a total of million in matching funds most candidates ran as republicans or democrats two third-party candi dates also qualified for public funds convention funding is a fixed amount indexed to inflation in each major party received million to conduct its presidential nominating con vention how do candidates spend their funds candidates spend the checkoff dollars on campaign advertising campaign staff campaign travel fundraising and other campaign expenses they may not use the federal money for personal expenses or for any purpose not related to the campaign does anyone monitor candidates use of funds yes at the end of every presidential election the fec audits the campaigns that receive public funds any unused funds or funds that were not spent for campaign purposes must be returned to the treasury since approximately million has been returned to the treasury who administers the checkoff program the fec administers and enforces the public funding program for example the agency certifies the eligibility of the candidates and the amount of matching funds primary candidates receive audits the committees that receive public funds publishes the campaign finance data reported by the candidates and committees and investigates alleged violations when justified and may initiate civil court actions to enforce the law the irs monitors the flow of checkoff dollars into the fund and the treasury department makes the actual payments to candidates and committees is the checkoff used for administering the public funding program no all of the checkoff money is used for funding presidential elections costs of administering the program are covered by the fec budget appropriated each year by congress what would happen if checkoff dollars ran short if a shortfall occurred in the presidential fund the secretary of the treasury would allocate the remain ing funds among the eligible candidates and committees the law requires that priority be given first to party nominating conventions then to general election nominees and last to primary election candidates if there were insufficient funds for the primary election candidates the treasury would provide only partial matching funds does checking yes increase my tax checking the yes box does not increase the amount of tax you owe nor does it decrease any refund to which you are entitled the taxpayer choice in establishing the checkoff program congress left the single most important decision to you the taxpayer you decide whether you want three dollars of your tax to be used for the presidential funding program described in this brochure the choice is yours to voluntarily check yes or no the fund is not a separate account but is actually part of the treasury in order to qualify for matching funds a candidate in the primary elections must first raise over in each of states over consisting of small contributions or less from individuals

column3: fda talk paper food and drug administration department of health and human services public health service fishers lane rockville md fda talk papers are prepared by the press office to guide fda personnel in responding with consistency and accuracy to questions from the public on subjects of current interest talk papers are subject to change as more information becomes available judith foulke july nutrition information on restaurant menus the food and drug administration today set standards for the claims that can be made in restaurant menus for the nutritional values of individual foods and meals to ensure that consumers get what they order this final rule will mean that if claims like low fat or heart healthy are made on a restaurant menu the restaurant owner must be able to demonstrate that there is a reasonable basis for believing that the food qualifies to bear this claim the rule allows restaurants considerable flexibility in establishing this reasonable basis and in presenting the information to consumers this final rule affects only those restaurateurs who place claims such as low fat or heart healthy on their menus these restaurateurs must be prepared to show officials that their menu claims are consistent with the claim definitions established under the nutrition labeling and education act of nlea unlike processed foods restaurant menu selections are not required to supply complete nutrition information also unlike processed foods menu items bearing a claim are not held to the same strict standards of laboratory analyses other more economical methods can be used to meet the standard for example a restaurant could show that an item was designed to meet the requirements for the claim because it was prepared using a recipe from a recognized health professional association or dietary group or that the nutritional values for the dish were calculated using a reliable nutrition data base furthermore nutrition information can be provided to the consumer by any reasonable means it does not have to be presented in the nutrition facts format seen on packaged food labels nor does it have to appear on the menu a restaurant for example may compile in a notebook information on the fat content of all menu items that bear fat claims so long as the nutrition information is available to consumers upon request fda estimates that the rule flexibility and its limited scope should minimize its economic impact on the restaurant industry to further reduce the possible economic burden on restaurants they will be given until may to come into compliance with the new regulation the new menu rules are identical to the standards that have been in effect since may for nutrient content claims on placards and signs in large and medium-sized restaurants and since may for smaller restaurants in fact restaurateurs seeking guidance for complying with new menu regulations can consult the sections of fda august guidance on food labeling that deal with claims on restaurant signs and placards copies of this document food labeling questions and answers volume ii a guide for restaurants and other retail establishments can be obtained through the superintendent of documents government printing office washington the district court of washington on june ordered fda to finalize regulations for restaurant menu labeling the court issued its decision in response to a lawsuit filed by consumer groups seeking to include restaurant menus under the provisions of nlea the court agreed with the plaintiff argument that the nlea specifically required that restaurants could only make nutritional and health claims that were consistent with fda regulations

column3: the international bioethics education and career development award release date march rfa fogarty international center letter of intent receipt date april application receipt date may purpose the fogarty international center fic in partnership with the national institute of allergy and infectious diseases niaid the national institute of nursing research ninr the national institute of child health and human development nichd the national heart lung and blood institute nhlbi the national institute on drug abuse nida the national institute of general medical sciences nigms the national institute of arthritis and musculoskeletal and skin diseases niams and the national center for complementary and alternative medicine nccam invites applications from nonprofit private or public domestic or international educational and research institutions to develop or expand on current graduate curricula in international bioethics related to performing research in low- and middle-income nations the curricula will provide a core set of advanced study courses that primarily focus on the internationally relevant aspects of the ethical legal and social principles guiding the responsible conduct of research in developing countries particularly on scientific integrity and the protection of the interests of research participants support will be provided for advanced multi-disciplinary training for developing country health professionals working at institutions conducting biomedical behavioral or public health research involving human and animal subjects as well as ethicists or philosophers from developing countries with no prior experience in research support may also be included for the development and implementation of intensive short courses designed specifically for individuals directly involved in human subjects research ethical review and in conducting clinical trials in developing countries this rfa contributes to the initiative to strengthen research bioethics training for individuals from the developing world the fic recognizes that highly trained individuals from a number of disciplines are needed in order to provide guidance to the research community on ethical questions that arise during the conduct of transcultural research this rfa is intended to stimulate the development of new didactic programs in relevant issues in international bioethics at institutions that either do not currently offer such programs or at institutions with existing didactic programs in international bioethics to support or expand their programs to include a major focus on issues relevant to developing countries it is expected that such high- quality didactic training for career development of individuals from developing countries will strengthen bioethical expertise at the host institutions as well as within national governments and international bodies trainees may also subsequently pursue culturally relevant studies on ethical practice in biomedical and behavioral research the goal of this initiative is to increase the cadre of developing country biomedical and behavioral scientists clinical investigators nurses and other health professionals and relevant academics and to provide them with state-of-the-art knowledge of ethical considerations concepts and methods in research involving human and animal subjects upon completion of their training developing country participants supported by this rfa are expected to return to independent and productive careers including training and consultation research in bioethics within their home institutions healthy people the public health service phs is committed to achieving the health promotion and disease prevention objectives of healthy people a phs-led national activity for setting priority areas this request for applications rfa international bioethics education and career development award is related to the priority area of human resource development potential institutions should have a substantial biomedical and clinical research portfolio including faculty conducting significant biomedical or behavioral research in developing countries an institution may submit only one application applicants are encouraged to develop consortia with other or international institutions to enhance the depth of their faculty and participant pool or to improve the quality of the educational experience participants developing country candidates for international bioethics training will be selected by the applicant institutions since ethics is a multidisciplinary field background this initiative is intended to attract talented individuals in developing countries to the challenges of transcultural bioethics and to equip them with the critical skills that are needed to enable them to provide expertise and leadership to their institutions national governments and international bodies and potentially to pursue culturally relevant studies on ethical practice in biomedical and behavioral research few developing country institutions provide formal training in bioethics few advanced bioethics training programs focus in depth on the internationally relevant aspects of bioethics particularly those related to clinical investigations in developing countries while other nih programs support some short-term training courses in research bioethics only a few trainees are from the developing world few developing country health professionals conducting laboratory or clinical investigations have received extensive formal training in the principles of bioethics the primary rules and codes of ethical research ethical experimentation on vertebrate animals the components of informed consent in transcultural settings decision-making related to collaborative agreements between host and sponsors of clinical research elements of study design that affect the ethical conduct of clinical trials or interventions that should be provided to study participants therefore the specific objectives of this initiative are to improve the quality of international ethics training by supporting the development of didactic courses in fundamental areas needed to provide skills for teaching and research related to bioethics and the conduct of medical research in developing countries to support advanced training for a cadre of developing country professionals who could assume the roles and responsibilities of bioethicists involved in ethics review or clinical trial design in the academic laboratory clinical or public health settings of research and clinical investigations in their countries a program this award provides support for up to four years to allow institutions to develop a comprehensive ethics curriculum with a focus on the ethics of conducting research in developing countries and to train a cohort of developing country participants applications may be submitted from educational and research institutions that do not currently provide such a didactic program as well as to those that propose to expand well-established international ethics training programs applicants must provide a detailed description of the proposed program including courses offered frequency of classes selection criteria for participants entering the program and target goal of enrollment into the program if planned activities include short courses applicants should provide detailed descriptions of well- justified specifically targeted intensive curricula designed for individuals directly involved in human subjects research ethical review or in conducting clinical trials in developing countries b program director the award will support the principal director to manage coordinate and evaluate and with associated faculty to design develop implement and refine as needed an international bioethics curriculum the program director should possess the international bioethics expertise leadership and administrative capabilities required to create an interdisciplinary didactic program he or she should be currently engaged in ethics research as well as in the mentoring of new investigators a minimum of of the program professional effort is required during the first year c faculty sufficient numbers of faculty should be involved in the proposed curriculum development and training who have a record of providing the type of instruction required under this award faculty trained in ethics philosophy clinical research and public health are recommended faculty should also be accomplished investigators and graduate training mentors the proposed faculty should be actively engaged in the design and conduct of bioethical research and also have demonstrated a successful record in obtaining peer reviewed federal and non-federal funding for such activities the capability of the participating faculty to develop advanced curricula instruct and fully train individuals to pursue careers in international bioethics must be documented the training faculty are encouraged to consult with at least one individual from a developing country with expertise in conducting research or who is familiar with ethics review procedures in their home country training faculty should also include individuals with experience in the design of biomedical including clinical or behavioral research in developing countries the percent of faculty effort planned for course development instruction and mentoring trainees should be described d curriculum the curriculum should be designed to provide a maximum of two years degree level graduate training but could also accommodate non-degree seeking participants with other professional degrees and different levels of experience in bioethics the core curriculum developed should ideally be case-based it may include an array of bioethics-related topics of general interest such as the history and principles of human and animal research ethical perspectives on the use of human biological materials in research the ethics of designing clinical research protocols and ethical considerations in performing research in vulnerable populations with an emphasis on transcultural research other topics may include international codes and guidelines informed consent collaborative agreements between host and sponsor countries the role of ethics review committees in the developing world and in cross-cultural research and ethnographic research the curriculum should include training in the methodology to pursue culturally relevant studies on ethical theory and practice in biomedical and behavioral research the scope and format for presenting the core curriculum can be flexible to meet the perceived needs of the trainees and faculty the program may also include advanced specialized courses in ethics related to epidemiology public health human rights justice and economics the detailed description of the content of proposed courses and the potential benefit to developing country trainees should be included in the training plan the curriculum developed must begin to be offered to trainees within one year of the award and should be initiated during the first year of support if feasible e training the award provides support for up to two years and no less than months of advanced bioethics training for developing country trainees in addition institutions may propose providing support for appropriate candidates to earn a master degree in a relevant area public health research bioethics clinical research the proposed program should also have the column3: summary report craniofacial genetic diseases and disorders workshop bethesda marriortt hotel bethesda maryland june contents workshop summary background final recommendations conclusions workshop proceedings welcoming session opening session session genetic and environmental influences session animal and in vitro embryology new technologies session therapeutic approaches concluding session appendices agenda participant list hoshin process nidr convened an international workshop on inherited craniofacial diseases and disorders involving nidr-supported scientists and institute staff in identifying research opportunities defining infrastructure needs and laying the groundwork for collaborations invited participants took part in three working group sessions using a modified hoshin facilitation process to elicit maximum input from all participants and to distill responses into prioritized lists of research recommendations the report that follows discusses the work of the breakout groups as well as the remarks of speakers throughout the workshop background congenital defects occur in almost percent of live births in the united states three-quarters of these include oral-dental-craniofacial defects the national institute of dental research nidr has from its founding in supported research on these devastating disorders today the institute supports large extramural and intramural research programs that seek to understand the pathological mechanisms that underlie craniofacial defects and to improve treatment and prevention strategies to ensure that the institute remains in close association with the extramural research community and is aware of the latest research opportunities nidr invited an international assembly of bench and clinical scientists to participate in an advisory workshop the craniofacial genetic diseases and disorders workshop was held in bethesda maryland on june the workshop was structured to elicit recommendations from a broad range of experts concerning the most effective way for nidr to facilitate advances in the knowledge and treatment of craniofacial birth defects the three working sessions addressed genetic and environmental influences animal and in vitro embryology new technologies and therapeutic approaches speakers gave short presentations to introduce each session and to stimulate creative thinking during the sessions each participant submitted recommendations to advance progress in the area the working groups then prioritized the recommendations by determining which of them would facilitate the largest number of advances in the last workshop session the participants prioritize final recommendations based on their overall scientific importance the final recommendations from both types of analysis will be used by nidr in charting future directions for research support into the century final recommendations workshop recommendations were prioritized initially by determining which advances would facilitate progress in the largest number of other areas initial recommendations the lists of final recommendations were compiled from the initial recommendations by ballot according to priority based on their overall importance to the field session genetic and environmental influences participants identified several broad areas that need encouragement from nidr for example more resources are needed in the search for genetic causes of craniofacial defects in addition since it is difficult to locate sufficient numbers of patients with the same birth defect it was recommended that registries be established to facilitate study of these anomalies registries would promote studies that identify genes relate genotype to phenotype and identify populations at genetic environmental risk the registries also would identify patient populations appropriate for therapeutic clinical trials the need for a more thorough understanding of normal and abnormal craniofacial development by increasing knowledge in developmental biology and animal studies also was highlighted this topic was addressed in more detail in session final recommendations for session are listed below improve phenotypic delineation as well as gene identification and characterization increase understanding of developmental biology both generally and in specific models gene expression and bone and craniofacial organogenesis support animal studies including models of craniofacial and skeletal disorders develop informatics databases and registries study environmental influences such as teratogens nutrition and smoking on craniofacial development session animal and in vitro embryology new technologies two primary areas in which progress can be made were highlighted more needs to be learned about the genetic and regulatory pathways that control cell lineage and gene regulation in normal and abnormal oral-dental-craniofacial development genetic pathways and other regulation of cell activities control the differentiation and fate of multipotent embryonic cells and thus regulate embryonic patterning and tissue formation it is necessary first to understand normal development in order to understand how intervening events cause birth defects the second major set of recommendations supports the first establish of mutant animals human tissues cdna antibodies and other analytical tools along with better in vitro models such banks would provide convenient access to much-needed material for genetic and biochemical studies of normal and abnormal genes proteins and cellular processes this material and other tools also would be valuable for genetic and pharmacological tests of potential new therapies in vitro the five highest-ranked final recommendations from session are listed below elucidate genetic pathways and other regulators of cell and tissue activities and develop cell-fate maps create mutant animal models and repositories investigate mechanisms of tissue-specific gene expression develop analytical tools cdna libraries antibodies and tissue banks develop and improve in vitro culture methods and models session therapeutic approaches while reiterating the contributions provided by registries animal models and libraries and banks clinicians also described the difficulties that exist in diagnosing patients with birth defects craniofacial birth defects occur as both isolated dysmorphologies and as part of complex syndromes currently not enough is known about the etiologies of widely variable patient phenotypes to enable clinicians to form prognoses or even to identify the most appropriate treatment or repair procedures much more research is needed to develop genetic diagnostic methods to correlate genotypes with phenotypes and to understand pathways of development so that useful diagnoses can be made in addition new approaches in the use of animal models and in cell and tissue engineering are needed additionally randomized clinical trials are needed to ensure that treatments and repairs are efficacy-based many patients are treated in early infancy and very little research has been conducted to determine the optimal patient age for treatment or the most effective permanent treatment protocols for growing children and older patients the top five final recommendations for session are listed below conduct randomized clinical trials develop animal models elucidate pathways in normal development establish methods for genetic diagnosis develop methodologies for cell and tissue engineering conclusions the participants in this workshop have provided nidr with insights and recommendations that will be invaluable in helping the institute determine how best to support research that will increase the rate of progress in the field of oral-dental-craniofacial birth defects these recommendations will help the institute make decisions about new activities to ensure that funds provided to support scientific projects will be used optimally utilizing new resources to make progress even more efficient and productive a complete listing of all of the specific suggestions provided by each of the participants as well as the numerical scores for all recommendations are available upon request from office of the director nidr workshop proceedings welcoming session phenotypic expression of genetic defects drs linda thomas and kenneth yamada welcomed participants to the sunday evening june opening session they clarified the purpose of the workshop as advising the national institute of dental research about areas of scientific opportunity that will advance biomedical research on the etiology prevention diagnosis and treatment of inherited dental-oral-craniofacial diseases the two chairs ethylin jabs and bjorn olsen gave presentations at the sunday evening welcoming session ethylin jabs professor departments of pediatrics medicine and plastic surgery and director center for craniofacial development and disorders johns hopkins university school of medicine baltimore md in discussing correlations jabs noted that approximately percent of all newborns and an additional percent of infants and children by the age of years are found to have birth defects percent have minor anomalies of the over genetic syndromes known over have defects and over have associated clefting many different classes of genes or proteins when mutated cause craniofacial-dental-oral defects and these include transcription factors growth factors and their receptors hormone receptors cell adhesion molecules g proteins enzymes transporters and collagens the chromosomal map location is known for over inherited craniofacial disorders and the genes are known for more than abnormalities an overview of these human conditions and key examples elucidating their molecular pathophysiology were presented the van der woude syndrome locus has been mapped to chromosome and research is actively being conducted to positionally clone this disease gene as well as others moebius syndrome locus was recently identified to be on chromosome periodontitis-juvenile form amelogenesis imperfecta and dentinogenesis imperfecta loci are all present in the chromosome region and could represent genetically separate conditions a contiguous gene syndrome or allelic conditions similarly orofacial cleft and oculodentodigital dysplasia loci both map to chromosome and cohen syndrome locus maps to chromosome the jacobsen syndrome locus is present on chromosome and is associated with a fragile site and expanding trinucleotide repeat is a chromosome deletion syndrome and opitz syndrome maps to the same region waardenburg syndrome an autosomal dominant condition with high penetrance and variable expressivity is an important example of how precise phenotypic description can assist in predicting genotypes in this condition affected individuals have different phenotypes yet share the same abnormal gene or may look quite similar but have mutations on different genes in waardenburg type patients display uneven spacing of the eyes deafness and uneven skin coloration waardesnburg type patients have craniofacial-hand-deafness abnormalities however both conditions are associated with mutations in the same gene a paired-box and homeobox gene is located on chromosome waardenburg type patients have the same features as types and except that the eye placement is normal and the genetic mutation is in another gene mitf on chromosome both partial anodontia and boston type craniosynostosis are caused by mutations in the msx family of homeobox transcription factors in one form of partial anodontia an mutation on chromosome results perhaps in a dominant negative effect in boston type craniosynostosis there is an gain-of-function mutation on chromosome fibroblast growth factor receptors fgfrs are involved in other conditions with craniosynostosis such as thanatophoric dysplasia type with mutations in the intracellular tyrosine kinase domain of and crouzon pfeiffer jackson-weiss apert and beare-stevenson syndrome with mutations in the extracellular and transmembrane domains of pfeiffer syndrome can be caused by mutations in and and crouzon syndrome can be caused by mutations in and in addition the same mutation can cause more than one syndrome all of these mutations cause constitutive activation of the receptor independent of ligands and they do not always appear to be associated with direct correlations suggesting there are modifying genes either downstream or upstream of fgfrs in signaling transduction pathways in drosophila expression of the twist gene is required for homologue of fgfr expression showing that twist regulates fgfr it is interesting that twist might also be upstream of fgfr and also regulates fgfr expression in humans because twist mutations have been found to cause a phenotype similar to fgfr mutations twist haploinsufficiency results in another autosomal dominant condition saethre-chotzen syndrome that also includes craniosynostosis mice heterozygous null for twist have a similar phenotype and can serve as an animal model system these studies are helping to elucidate normal developmental pathways and pathophysiology of these conditions in humans as well as treatment modalities jabs suggested the following areas need further development definitive clinical diagnostic criteria clinical testing to accomplish clinical delineation animal models that correspond to human phenotypes identification of genes that cause birth defects in humans and identification of the same genes in animal models correlations identifying genes their modifiers and their regulation dna testing treatment developmental treatment databases registries tissue banks functional studies consortia international studies industries bjorn olsen hersey professor of cell biology harvard-forsyth professor of oral biology and chair of harvard forsyth department of oral biology harvard medical school boston ma bjorn olsen began his remarks by calling for multidisciplinary research approaches and collaborations he then described two examples of disorders with opportunities for treatment prevention based on studies the first opportunity he addressed was cleidocranial dysplasia ccd which is caused by mutations in the gene in humans is found on chromosome the murine gene is located in the corresponding region of chromosome two excellent mouse models for this condition exist in humans secondary tooth eruption is delayed supernumerary secondary teeth are present clavicles are abno rmally formed and stature is short spina bifida also may occur and cranial sutures and fontanels do not close in mice homozygous for knockout alleles there is a complete lack of bone cartilage is present but it is not converted to bone furthermore mesenchyme does not form osteoblasts so osteoblasts are not present the osteoblast-specific gene osteocalcin is regulated by different human ccd pedigrees show loss of the gene loss of function the mutations include insertions deletions and missense mutations that lead to haploinsufficiency the current goal is to identify the mechanisms involved the clavicle provides an interesting example of tissue-specific effects the lateral region of the clavicle consists of membraneous bone where collagen type and osteopontin are expressed the medial region consists of endochondral bone in which collagen type ii and sox are initially expressed later collagen type ii aggrecan and collagen type x are expressed in the medial region in ccd the medial region of the clavicle is missing chondrocytes do not form in this area the need now is to identify the upstream and downstream targets involved in function a treatment for cleidocranial dysplasia may be to double the expression level of a researcher at harvard stuart schreiber is developing rapid screens for the effects of drug compounds on cellular activities this might be an efficient way to identify drugs that stimulate expression of the gene the second area of research opportunity discussed by olsen involved venous malformations that create large tumor-like growths the current treatment is to inject alcohol but this is not particularly effective inherited cerebral venous malformations have been linked to a locus on chromosome while a muco-cutaneous form is caused by a mutation in endothelial-specific receptor tyrosine kinase an a-to-t mutation in the kinase domain of the endothelialcell receptor is associated with the dominant phenotype the receptor dimerizes after ligand binding and the mutation may alter dimerization two affected families one italian and one german have the same point mutation in the gene the mutation results in a fold increase in kinase activity and causes affected veins in the malformations to have little or no smooth muscle in their walls the tie ligand is angiopoietin i and a feedback loop between the endothelium and smooth muscle in the presence of decreased ligand produces a phenotype similar to tie mutations both and tie may be involved in other more general disorders for example osteoporosis and atherosclerosis respectively in each of these studies olsen strongly emphasized the importance of collaborations opening session speaker harold slavkin director national institute of dental research nih nidr director harold slavkin began the first session by remarking on the history of the institute he called for collaboration with other institutes and agencies in carrying out research and training in inherited and acquired craniofacial-oral-dental diseases and disorders he encouraged the workshop participants to consider not only the classical mendelian patterns of inheritance but to include the more complex patterns of environment-gene interactions that result in craniofacial syndromes and craniofacial-oral-dental diseases and disorders the opportunities for health promotion prevention improved diagnostics therapeutics and basic science provide significant opportunities for the biomedical research community the term craniofacial biology was coined by professor sam pruzansky in the late that was a time when craniofacial teams were created to address the demanding treatment requirements for infants born with craniofacial dysmorphogenesis importantly when considering the future of craniofacial biology genetics and treatments in the late no one anticipated the profound implications of the biological and information revolutions such as the human genome project informatics molecular genetics transgenic animal models and health care management changes finally slavkin challenged the workshop participants to take a fresh look at how the national institute of dental research in partnership with numerous possible collaborators can support significant contributions to health promotion disease prevention smarter diagnostics and therapeutics and fundamental knowledge in behavioral and other biological sciences and in these discussions and analyses he urged the workshop participants to address a few important questions does the institute have the research capacity to undertake these issues is retraining needed to facilitate creative research are people sufficiently multilingual in the diverse disciplines that constitute the craniofacial-oral-dental research community slavkin suggested that the federal government may serve as the instrument through which research on animal models may be applied to human patients the high prevalence of craniofacial diseases offers opportunities for clinical basic cytogenetic and other international research collaborations he wished the participants well in their deliberations session genetic and environmental influences bjorn olsen chair speaker jeffrey murray professor department of pediatrics and biological sciences and director nidr-supported craniofacial center university of iowa murray presented an overview of current knowledge regarding gene identification and environmental influences particularly as they relate to nonsyndromic clefting he hoped to set the stage for the breakout groups where more substantive discussion will take place and acknowledged that all the answers to craniofacial anomalies will not be found in the next five years scientists have their greatest challenge in the nonsyndromic anomalies caused by complex interactions between genes and environmental factors strategic approaches to gene identification include positional cloning animal models and candidate genes the human genome project will provide information on the regulatory genes that govern human existence and the new data will allow researchers to study tens of thousands of individuals each person has about million differences from the next person but most genetic variation does not lead to abnormality environmental factors that play a role in complex dysmorphologies include infections particularly viral and including nutritional substances determining how these components influence susceptibility is a challenge in which the international health community can make significant contributions the gene-environment interactions seen with smoking and folic acid intake are very common influences long-range considerations for research in this area are genetic variability understanding sequence data application to disease discovery and application to prevention and treatment speaker william shaw professor of orthodontics and dentofacial development university of manchester england shaw addressed the subject of international collaborative oral health research on craniofacial anomalies cfas in under the title solving health problems through global cooperation the world health organization who and the federation dentaire international fdi presented a five-item agenda for international collaborative oral health research cfas were one of the five original agenda items and remain on the growing list in the present initiative to establish an active international collaborative research agenda shaw acknowledged that this initiative is flourishing at a time when a similar call is being made at the global level for identification of the major health-related research topics needed to carry us through the next to years the who through its advisory committee on health research is pursuing that call energetically emphasizing that all sectors that have important effects on health must be part of the campaign not only to identify but also to implement those main lines of research craniofacial birth defects affect an important proportion of the global society cleft lip palate for example occur in approximately per births but that rate varies widely among regions and nations the costs in terms of morbidity health care and emotional disturbance resulting from cfas are considerable to affected individuals and their families and to society in general shaw noted that current research efforts and efforts to resister patients with cfas show little evidence of coherent strategy recent advances in gene mapping and transgenesis within the background of the human genome project would benefit greatly from a strategic global overview of cfas similarly research on the prevention and treatment of cfas is poorly advanced and would be accelerated by international partnerships concerted international action on cfas promises a number of outcomes shaw cited the following an international database of gene sequences for an increasing range of cfas enhanced understanding of gene functions and the environment and identification of factors governing the variation across populations recommendations on dietary supplements and other interventions for effective public health programs to reduce the risk for cfas recommendations on optional treatments and models of delivery of care for cfas in addition to the benefits of traditional dissemination of knowledge and exchanges of scientific personnel certain topics in craniofacial research gain significant added value from an international approach the first two are discussed elsewhere in the workshop and are referenced here briefly international genetic epidemiology the prevalence of craniofacial anomalies in some locations is higher than in others sometimes markedly so a systematic approach combining clinical epidemiology and appropriate molecular genetics technology could rapidly yield a crop of new diagnoses international studies of prevention case-control studies of gene-environment interaction leading to possible prevention studies involving periconceptional supplementation of vitamins and other nutrients offer the possibility of preventing cleft lip and palate however the sample sizes required for such work will commonly call for a multinational approach such as that taken in the medical research council folate trial international studies of treatment the advancement of clinical knowledge of craniofacial anomalies has been limited by small samples anecdotal and biased reporting and lack of multicenter collaboration few clinical questions have been addressed by research designs that meet the rigors of contemporary health technology assessment well-organized treatment centers with large case loads standardized protocols and the capability to collect and maintain clinical records hold the key to establishing reliable evidence for defining and refining clinical protocols comparisons between different protocols typically require group sizes of or more cases with strictly defined anomalies if statistical power and reliability is to be achieved meaningful research frequently will call for an international approach given the fragmented nature of cleft and craniofacial services in most countries this appears to be a particular problem in the us at present since the advent of hmos as the eurocleft study demonstrated intercenter comparisons of clinical outcome can reveal dramatic shortcomings in the delivery and quality of clefting care poor outcomes and the need for multiple secondary operations in the uk were linked to decentralized care by low volume teams as a result of which a complete government restructuring of clinical services is underway equivalent work in different regions of the world will undoubtedly promote improvements elsewhere in the provision of care for individuals with craniofacial anomalies randomized controlled trials are required to provide an adequate evidence base for the health technologies associated with craniofacial care such as the techniques timing and sequencing of surgery again few countries on their own have the clinical resources to mount clinical trials of sufficient scale to provide the answers required proposed framework shaw noted that there is a pressing need to develop a global register of scientists laboratories and clinical teams with a major involvement in craniofacial anomalies some infrastructure already exists that can be built upon for example the european community currently provides grants to support research networking throughout europe in surveillance genetic services and other clinical services including quality assurance the cochrane collaboration is an existing global effort whose goal is to prepare and maintain systematic reviews of randomized controlled trials related to oral health and craniofacial anomalies breakout group initial recommendations session group a create of southern california shuler discussed animal model research applications particularly those regarding diagnosis and etiology he sought to address four questions what is possible what will be possible what could or should be developed how will this advance our understanding alternative species model systems that can be developed in vivo include whole animal organ-specific tissue-specific availability for interventions and the opportunity to examine and track subject cells to the very end other approaches to alter molecular mechanisms in vitro include receptor inhibition or stimulation antisense oligonucleotides transgenic tissues inducible gene expressions and other means that are impossible in vivo organ culture model systems let the researcher use specific molecules to replace a function and then begin to molecularly dissect what is really happening it is possible to go back to eight days of embryo development in knockout mice and trace subsequent development in vitro cell health and human development nih dawid spoke on the value of zebrafish as a model for studying craniofacial development the zebrafish offers rapidly developing transparent embryos the ability to contain a large number of adult fish in a small space high fecundity saturation screens that have already been done and an available genetic linkage map the embryo is similar to that of mammals and has an abundance of markers to identify organs and other systems zebrafish almost parallel mouse as a research tool on human development and dawid expects new genes to be isolated in fish that have biological and genetic-based therapies in animal models session therapeutic approaches drs ethylin jabs and bjorn olsen chairs speaker marilyn jones director cleft and craniofacial treatment program children hospital san diego ca jones focused on current treatment approaches for patients with craniofacial anomalies she said that children do not go untreated in this country as they do in many parts of the world however treatment is largely empirical as randomized studies of various techniques have not been done in addition the rapid shift to managed care has posed new challenges to treatment because as some plans have transferred care from major centers with experience to individual practitioners in medicine and dentistry with little to no appropriate background in the united states treatment protocols are dictated by geography for example a child born in florida might have a fixed appliance screwed into the palate in advance of lip repair whereas a child in another part of the country might have a single-stage lip repair no controls are placed on these therapies and no one knows which approach is better attention needs to be paid to subtle discriminators of cleft type for better descriptive classification randomized clinical trials are very much needed to confirm and evaluate diagnostic and treatment approaches medical and dental schools offer one logical venue for such endeavors two systems for classifying craniofacial defects also contribute to the acknowledged confusion in the field those classified by morphology or shape are treated by surgeons those identified by etiology or developmental pathogenesis are the subjects of specialists such as the participants in this workshop the two systems do not interdigitate but they need to do so in the best interests of the children involved those with syndromic clefting need to be identified to ensure their thorough diagnosis and treatment speaker clair francomano chief medical genetics branch examples of therapy at the level of the gene product or the gene itself are seen as to where we would like to be goals include prevention of the major causes of morbidity and mortality in genetic disorders clinical therapy based on sound science and rational interventions based not only on the signs and symptoms of disease but on knowledge of its pathogenesis accomplishing these goals requires legitimate diagnostic criteria natural history studies knowledge of disease genes and their modifying loci and rational approaches to interrupt pathogenesis francomano cited three studies by scriver and childs and their colleagues as work in the literature that takes a comprehensive look at how scientists treat genetic disease the effect of mendelian disease on human health costa scriver and childs am j med genet looks at more than conditions surveying age at onset involvement of systems and organs impact on longevity and reproduction and impact on social adaptation treatment of mendelian disease hayes costa scriver and childs am j med genet reports on the effects of treatment on longevity reproduction somatic growth intellectual development social adaptation and cosmetic impairment group facilitator collects the post-its from group members reading the ideas out loud and then posting them at random on flip-chart sheets on the wall of the meeting room when all ideas have been posted group members go to the wall and work together at rearranging the post-its into columns of ideas with similar themes they then assign a descriptive title to each thematic group these titles will become potential nidr initiatives the facilitator draws a large circle on a flip chart and writes the theme titles at different points around the circle discussion then proceeds on the relationship between the different titles specifically which drives another is required before the other can be accomplished and which must be driven arrows are drawn from drivers to drivees titles with the greatest numbers of out arrows are prime drivers the current state of progress in each theme area is determined as a level from to percent the facilitator prepares a table showing each theme
